div.p: On April 23, the Board will hold a budget hearing at 3 p.m. and a committee meeting at 5 p.m. Find materials and full information HERE.

The School District of Philadelphia will remain closed for the rest of the school year due to COVID-19.
NEW: Grab-and-go meal distribution at our 49 District school sites will be shifting to one day per week. Learn more HERE. Sites are listed HERE.
4/20: For the latest update from Superintendent Hite, included updates on Chromebooks and supports, Digital Learning resources, how to connect with school-based staff, and calendar updates, visit our Coronavirus Information Hub.
Still need a Chromebook? Or help with yours? Remaining options, locations and times, and Tech Hotlines added to Chromebook Loaner Program HERE. Internet info/resources are HERE.
PreK-12 Learning Guides are available at all District meal sites & online (with other remote learning resources) HERE. PreK will also mail Guides home.
Have questions? Call our Hotlines (available in 10 languages), email us at covid19info@philasd.org or visit our Frequently Asked Questions webpage.

p.strong: April 21: Grab-and-go meal distribution at our 49 District school sites will be shifting to one day per week.

div.p: Every Thursday, beginning April 23, from 9 a.m. to noon, you will be able to pick up a box of 5 breakfast meals, five lunch meals and a ½ gallon of milk for each student in your family. Each box weighs six pounds so we encourage you to bring a wheeled cart or some other way to easily carry the boxes if you are picking up meals for multiple students in your household.

The one-day-per-week schedule is a proactive measure we are taking to further support the City’s shelter-in-place guidance, minimize social interactions and help flatten the coronavirus curve. Social distancing, the use of masks and gloves, and other safety efforts will continue to be practiced to ensure everyone’s safety as meals are distributed. Thank you for supporting this important safety effort.

April 20: For the latest update from Dr. Hite sent April 20, please click on the language below. It includes updates on Chromebooks and supports, how to access Digital Learning resources, how to connect with school-based staff, and an update in the District’s calendar due to the change in the state’s Election Day from April 28th to June 2nd.
Still need a Chromebook? Or need help with yours? Updated info HERE.

Lesson plans for week of April 20 have been posted HERE. Teachers will be using these materials in Google Classroom to interact and engage students directly. Parents are able to view them however the materials were not designed for parents to use with their children independently.

p.strong: As new information becomes available it will be posted here. Please check back regularly for ongoing updates.
The School District of Philadelphia will remain closed for the rest of the school year due to COVID-19.

div.p: Calendar changes: On the current school calendar, Election Day was scheduled for Tuesday, April 28, and schools were scheduled to be closed. Due to COVID-19 concerns, the state has moved Election Day to June 2, 2020. Therefore, students will participate in digital learning on April 28 as a school day. Schools will now be closed on Tuesday, June 2 to ensure we honor the State’s Election Day on our calendar as we always do.

Chromebooks: The District will provide a Chromebook to every student who needs one for learning at home. Visit our Chromebook Loaner page, for more info, a list of helpful How-To resources to help you use the Chromebooks, the Student Signout Form (added 4/14), and answers to some FAQ’s. Internet access info and resources are detailed HERE.
4/20: Hotlines have been added for tech support.

Digital Learning: As we move to digital learning, we know parents and guardians are being asked to engage in new roles in their student’s learning. Materials, resources and information will be updated regularly HERE.

Meals: Grab-and-go meals for our students will continue to be available across the City. In an effort to further support the City’s shelter-in-place guidance, minimize social interactions and help flatten the coronavirus curve, distribution at our 49 District school sites will be shifting to one day per week.

Every Thursday, beginning April 23, from 9 a.m. to noon, you will be able to pick up a box of 5 breakfast meals, five lunch meals and a ½ gallon of milk for each student in your family. Each box weighs six pounds so we encourage you to bring a wheeled cart or some other way to easily carry the boxes if you are picking up meals for multiple students in your household. Social distancing, the use of masks and gloves, and other safety efforts will continue to be practiced to ensure everyone’s safety as meals are distributed. Thank you for supporting this important safety effort.
Grab-and-go meals locations and pickup times sites for all Philadelphia students remains listed HERE.

Learning Guides Math, ELA, science, and social studies Learning Guides for grades PreK – 12 are available online HERE. Families are encouraged to complete the lessons in the Guides and being Digital Learning on Monday April 20.

Hotlines: SDP Hotlines will be available in ten languages, to answer general questions about the school closure, meals, etc. Hotlines are listed below. They will operate Monday through Thursday, from 9:30 – 11:30 a.m.
Email your questions: You can now also email your questions to covid19info@philasd.org for reply.
FAQs: Answers, as quickly as we can provide them, to your questions during the closure, HERE. Check back often for updated information.
Parent Portal: Now more than ever it’s important to stay connected. Get updates fast with your Parent Portal Account.

div.h2: How can I help protect myself and others?

div.p: Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects
Avoid putting fingers in your mouth, ears, or eyes

p.img: Wash your hands regularly with soap and water for 20 seconds
Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze – and wash your hands afterward
If you are sick, stay home until your fever is gone for 24 hours

div.p: The School District of Philadelphia has a guide for how to talk to your kids about coronavirus.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) offers the most up-to-date information on COVID-19. For updates from CDC, please see the following:

li.a: CDC Interim Guidance for Administrators of US Childcare Programs and K-12 Schools to Plan, Prepare, and Respond to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
CDC Frequently Asked Questions and Answers: Coronavirus Disease-2019 (COVID-19) and Children

div.p: Schools can share relevant CDC fact sheets to help students, families, and staff understand COVID-19 along with steps they can take to protect themselves:

li.a: What you need to know about coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
What to do if you are sick
Stop the spread of germs – help prevent the spread of respiratory viruses like COVID-19

The Readiness Emergency Management for Schools (REMS) Technical Assistance (TA) Center website has useful information, resources, trainings, and tools for addressing infectious diseases, related topics, and protecting the school community.
